urlLink It's a good thing I got a photo the other day of this marigold my daughter picked out and planted, this morning I went out and all the yellow flowers have been neatly pruned. It is totally de-bloomed! The bright orange ones were untouched, only the yellow ones were eaten. I suspect deer...and now that I think of it, earlier this summer the deer ate the yellow portulaca moss roses down to the ground. Is there a pattern here? Do deer prefer to eat yellow flowers? I hope not, yellow is one of my favorite colors...

urlLink Cape Plumbago - (Plumbago auriculata) I'm pretty sure that's what this plant is. The girl at the nursery told me it was Chinese Plumbago, but it doesn't look anything like the pictures I've seen. It is tender to zone 8, which means I very well may lose it this winter. Purchased June 2004. It is supposed to prefer full sun, but I've got mine in part sun. It is very fresh looking, and has been in bloom nonstop since planting.

urlLink Purchased three in spring 2004; two are doing well, one is just barely hanging on. Most references say to plant in full sun, but I understand they prefer part sun in Texas. Mine may have just a little too much shade, the two are doing well but they are leaning out toward the sun. I plan to move them in a few weeks when it cools down a little. The foliage is a nice bluish-gray, and the fat flower spikes are very dark purple!

I read a couple of interesting articles on gardening in hay bales and I thought I'd give it a try. Here is the article from urlLink Nichols Garden Nursery , and here is a urlLink newspaper article . I couldn't find wheat straw bales, but I have access to various types of hay bales. I'll just have to deal with sprouting weed seeds. I set three bales up behind the vegetable garden Monday evening (August9, 2004) and wet them thoroughly. Yesterday I wet them and then poured Fish Solution over them, I am supposed to wet them every day for 10 days before planting. I ordered urlLink Nasturtium - Glorious Gleam Mix (Tropaeolum majus) from Nichols, and I haven't decided what else to plant. Maybe pickling cucumbers? The good thing about these hay bales is, after they have rotted down I'll have a new bed! I want a place to put perennials like herbs or asparagus, this will allow me to work over the main beds without disturbing them. :)

This spring I bought a flat of mondo grass (40 I think) and I think their situation was too sunny. Yesterday I moved some of it to the small tree circle, an even shadier spot. Hopefully they will hang on until the fall season. I still have about 20 more to move...

We moved to Central Texas a little over a year ago and bought a home on 1.49 acres, just east of the little city of urlLink Lampasas . The locals *snort* and say "hahaha, you have Sugar Loaf " when I say I live and garden east of town, (this must be what caliche is called.) I must say it is very different from the clay I gardened on in Maryland and Virginia, and the sand in Georgia. And the rocks! We have picked limestone pebbles, rocks and boulders out of the soil and used them for tree rings. We have also scavenged limestone blocks from building sites for use in the garden. I'll have to post pictures, I am really enjoying working with limestone... The average rainfall for this area is said to be only 19 inches a year. The problem is that when it finally does rain, it comes down two or three inches at a time and tries to rush to Pecan Creek instead of soaking in. So after reading every gardening book I could get my hands on at the little county library, I decided to build raised beds and begin with a small vegetable garden. So this winter, I drew out a 21-foot diameter circle with intersecting paths, and with the help of Dear J., edged the whole thing with blocks. Here is a picture of the site, this was Valentines Day 2004, and the only snow we've had in over a year! Then Darling J. brought me bunches and bunches of burlap sandbags, which we used as weedblock, and filled the sections with a truckload of lovelylovely organic garden soil from Nolan Creek Nursery, Nolanville, TX. Here's a picture early in the summer, this is my tomato section. I planted one each determinate, indeterminate and grape cluster tomato, two basil and one marigold in this quadrant. And yes, I know the tomato cages are upside-down, I couldn't get them through the burlap! They worked just fine with a boulder or two weighing them down...I am still getting tomatoes, even through the heat of the summer! J. has been taking sacksful in to work and racking up brownie points. This section has grown a lot since that picture was taken, I promise to take new pictures, maybe tomorrow...
